Name: Connector/Cable Mating Protection
Description: The Test System Hardware shall be designed so that cables cannot be reversed or plugged into the wrong connector.

Paragraphs: The Test System Hardware shall be designed so that cables cannot be reversed or plugged into the wrong connector.
The Test System Hardware shall be designed so that cables cannot be reversed or plugged into the wrong connector.

[text3] Reversed cables can lead to damage to the UUT when power is applied or bent pins when the cables are mated. It is important to prevent this from occurring as this can lead to significant rework and repair being required on the production UUT in question. In some rare cases, the UUT may be scrapped due to the expected repair cost. However, in some cases where limited connector mates are available, this may not be practical. Therefore, it is critical to work with the design engineering team early on in this process for mates to the UUT.

[validation_evidence$193] See Rationale and also if not applicable, identify the reason such as the connector mates are not reversible and no alternative exists. In such cases, the requirement may be updated to indicate that special labels or other visual indicators are to be used to protect the UUT From damage. The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Keyed Connectors/Cables
Description: All connectors and cables with keying shall be correctly keyed to their mating point.

Paragraphs: All connectors and cables with keying shall be correctly keyed to their mating point.
All connectors and cables with keying shall be correctly keyed to their mating point.

[text3] Often times keying is wrong on connectors. Built fixtures and drawings need to be inspected and connection must be demonstrated to ensure that the keying is properly documented and implemented in the test equipment.
[validation_evidence$193] The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Tier 1 Boundary Scan Coverage
Description:
The Test System shall be capable of performing Tier 1 Boundary Scan coverage of the UUT.

 

NOTE:

  • The descriptions for the various tiers are as described below and specific features may be articulated as decomposed requirements for different projects.

    • Tier 1:  Boundary Scan tests and programming accessible on the UUT only.  Typically requires simple connection of power and the JTAG bus to the UUT.  Actions that can be generated from the Bscan tool menu for Tier 1 level actions are Bscan chain check, interconnect screens between scannable devices on the chain, screens for memory devices accessible from a scannable device, and programming/configuration of memory devices accessible from a scannable device.

    • Tier 2:  External fixtured BScan I/O to expand coverage through edge connectors

    • Tier 3:  Everything else.  If you have to do scripting, cluster testing, non-bscan type sublevel elements are all Tier 3

Paragraphs: The Test System shall be capable of performing Tier 1 Boundary Scan coverage of the UUT.

The +15V rail must be >+13V before the +3.3V and +1.8V rails come up.


The +3.3V rail and +1.8V rails must ramp from 0V to operational level in no more than 12 ms.

It is advisable that the full power-up sequence take no longer than 20ms.

Name: Cooling Requirements
Description:
The Boundary Scan Test System shall be capable of cooling UX FPGA/Processor/Memory on the UUT.

 

NOTE: 

  • In some instances, programmed processors or FPGA running with boot code or high speed memory will need to be cooled by the test fixture to prevent damage to the device. UX should be replaced with the relevant device reference designator if there is a cooling requirement.
  • Is the UUT going to be running functional code and need the heat sinks? Or is it running in boundary scan/JTAG mode and not getting as hot?

Paragraphs: The Boundary Scan Test System shall be capable of cooling UX FPGA/Processor/Memory on the UUT.

Name: UX Device Programming
Description:
The Boundary Scan Test System shall be capable of programming UX device on the UUT.

 

NOTE:

  • Typically the software load procedure is not available at this point but this requirement likely decomposes to specific hardware I/Os that might enable this programming to be possible.
  • UX should be replaced with the appropriate reference designator of the device being programmed in both the requirement name as well as the requirement description.
  • Keep in mind: How many are being built? Do you need faster programming methods? Do you have an estimated programming time? Different options for programming?
  • Specify if a certain file type is needed for programming. (Make sure the design engineers are generating the correct file types for boundary scan programming. Boundary scan is only compatible with certain file types.)

Paragraphs: The Boundary Scan Test System shall be capable of programming UX device on the UUT.

Name: Boundary Scan
Description:
Objective:
To verify that the Boundary Scan Test System executes Boundary Scan tests using the XJTAG boundary scan software for UUTs where XJTAG is applicable.

Preconditions:

  1. The project boundary scan strategy identifies the selected UUT as “XJTAG applicable.”

  2. XJTAG is installed, licensed (if required), and accessible from the test station.

  3. The UUT is connected to the Boundary Scan Test System using the correct interface/harnessing required for boundary scan.

  4. The Boundary Scan Test System is in a ready state (no active faults preventing test execution).

Required Evidence / Artifacts:

  • Boundary scan execution log and/or report for the run

  • Evidence that identifies the tool used (XJTAG name/version, log header, report metadata, etc.)

Pass Criteria:

  • The boundary scan test executes successfully for the selected UUT, and the resulting evidence (log/report/metadata) explicitly identifies XJTAG as the tool used.

Paragraphs:
Objective:
To verify that the Boundary Scan Test System executes Boundary Scan tests using the XJTAG boundary scan software for UUTs where XJTAG is applicable.
The project boundary scan strategy identifies the selected UUT as “XJTAG applicable.”
XJTAG is installed, licensed (if required), and accessible from the test station.
The UUT is connected to the Boundary Scan Test System using the correct interface/harnessing required for boundary scan.
The Boundary Scan Test System is in a ready state (no active faults preventing test execution).
Boundary scan execution log and/or report for the run
Evidence that identifies the tool used (XJTAG name/version, log header, report metadata, etc.)

To verify all keyed connectors/cables are correctly keyed to their mating point.

Input:

  • Keyed cables/connectors

  • Ability to attempt mating for intended interfaces

Expected Output:
Each keyed connector mates smoothly only to its intended mating point without forcing; keying features align as designed.

Pass Criteria:

  • No interference/misalignment observed

Description:

DECAGON-REQ_RC-24

To verify tests requiring operator input are grouped at the beginning or end of the test sequence unless otherwise specified by SLP critical order.

Input:

  • Full test sequence definition
  • Identification of operator-input tests
  • SLP critical order constraints (if any)

Expected Output:
Operator-input tests appear as a contiguous group at the start or end of the sequence, except those explicitly placed elsewhere due to SLP critical order.

Pass Criteria:

  • All operator-input tests are grouped at start or end of the sequence
  • Any operator-input tests not in the group have documented SLP critical-order justification/reference

Name: Test Prompt Clarity, Consistency, and Auditability
Description:
Related Requirement:
DECAGON-REQ_RC-25

Objective:
To verify test prompts are consistent, clear, and auditable throughout.

Input:

  • End-to-end test sequence execution
  • Capture of operator prompts and operator responses
  • Prompt/event logging enabled

Expected Output:
Prompts are uniform in style/terminology, unambiguous in required action, and each prompt/response is recorded in an audit trail.

Pass Criteria:

  • For each prompt, the log captures prompt text (or prompt ID), timestamp, operator response/acknowledgment, and test step context
  • Prompts contain explicit action and acceptance criteria where applicable
  • No prompts require interpretation to proceed correctly

Paragraphs: Objective:To verify test prompts are consistent, clear, and auditable throughout.
Expected Output:Prompts are uniform in style/terminology, unambiguous in required action, and each prompt/response is recorded in an audit trail.

Name: Drive Discrete Signals High and Low
Description:
Related Requirement:
DECAGON-REQ_RC-66

Objective:
To verify the Boundary Scan Test System can drive specified discrete signals high and low logic levels.

Input:

  • Discrete signal list/table
  • UUT/CCA connected
  • Boundary scan control configured
  • Measurement points (scope/DMM/logic analyzer)

Expected Output:
Each listed signal can be driven to valid logic high and logic low as commanded.

Pass Criteria:

  • For each listed signal: command HIGH results in measured HIGH within defined threshold
  • For each listed signal: command LOW results in measured LOW within defined threshold
  • Transitions are repeatable
  • Logs capture commanded state and measured verification

Paragraphs: Objective:To verify the Boundary Scan Test System can drive specified discrete signals high and low logic levels.
Expected Output:Each listed signal can be driven to valid logic high and logic low as commanded.

Expected Output:
The system interfaces to P1, P2, P3 and provides electrical access consistent with design intent.

Name: Power Supply Specs and Power Continuity
Description:
Related Requirement:
DECAGON-REQ_RC-30

Objective:
To verify that the power supply specs are acceptable, and that power is applied to the correct pins

Input:

  • Programmable power supply specs
  • Load conditions representative of max current draw

Expected Output: 

voltages are correct on given pins

Pass Criteria:

  • Supply capability meets or exceeds the required power
  • Power is applied to the correct pins

 

Power-up Order

Notes

Signal Name

Voltage

Expected Current

CCA Connector-Pin #

+15 V +/- 0.5 V

< 0.5 Amps

P1-40

< 0.5 Amps

P1-2

2

The +15V rail must be >+13V before the +3.3V and +1.8V rails come up.


The +3.3V rail and +1.8V rails must ramp from 0V to operational level in no more than 12 ms.

 

The +3.3V and +1.8V rail startup ramp must occur within 8 ms of each other.

 

It is advisable that the full power-up sequence take no longer than 20ms.

 

Additionally: The +3.3 and +1.8V rails must ramp from operational level to 0V within 20 ms of each other on power-down.

Preconditions:

  • Display Processor UUT available.
  • Test system harness/fixture for Display Processor UUT available.
  • Interface documentation available identifying P5, P4, and P1 (P5/P4 = JTAG test, P1 = power).

  • Photos/screenshots as needed (connector mating/labeling).

Pass Criteria:

  • Connector identification and intended function match the interface documentation.

Name: Display Processor Tier 1 Boundary Scan Coverage Target
Description:
Related Requirement:
DECAGON-REQ_RC-62

Objective:
Verify the test system targets the specified Tier 1 boundary scan coverage potential on the Display Processor CCA.

Preconditions:

  • Boundary scan environment configured for Display Processor CCA.
  • Coverage reporting enabled in the boundary scan tool.
  • UUT variant is available (2600-1760-001 and/or 2600-1760-002).

Required Evidence / Artifacts:

  • Coverage report/log artifact for the run.
  • Record of selected UUT variant and tool version.

Pass Criteria:

  • Coverage report is generated for the selected UUT variant.
  • Report indicates coverage/targets consistent with the requirement table for the selected variant (including listed devices and programming)

 

  • Note:
  • Tier 1:  Boundary Scan tests and programming accessible on the UUT only. 
    • Typically requires simple connection of power and the JTAG bus to the UUT. 
    • Actions that can be generated from the Bscan tool menu for Tier 1 level actions are
      • Bscan chain check
      • Interconnect screens between scannable devices on the chain
      • Screens for memory devices accessible from a scannable device
      • Programming/configuration of memory devices accessible from a scannable device

Paragraphs:
Objective:
Verify the test system targets the specified Tier 1 boundary scan coverage potential on the Display Processor CCA.

Description:
The 828-1A60-001 Boundary Scan Application shall program and verify the files listed in the following table with respective FILE NAME, FILE ADDRESS RANGE, DEVICE START ADDRESS, FILL DATA, and FILE CRC.

 

 

NOTE: 

  • The programming parameters table comes from the CCA Drawing 828-1A60-001 Rev N.
  • Item 140 is 072-2874-002
  • Item 141 is 9833-0941-003
  • Verification of this requirement includes both inspection of the test software and a test run of the software.
    • Inspection verification involves inspecting the following elements in the test application software at a minimum: FILE NAME, FILE ADDRESS RANGE, DEVICE START ADDRESS, FILL DATA, FILE CRC, and the Device the respective file is programmed to.
    • Test verification involves the running of the programming and verify actions to ensure that both actions pass.
  • A bit by bit verification of the data which will be executed during the verification phase of this requirement to supersede verifying the Device Checksum after each load.
  • A verification of the data load will be executed using the vendor tool at the verification phase of this requirement to supersede verifying the Device Checksum after each load

Name: Hardware Scope
Description:
It is good practice to map out all of your hardware items that are needed as part of the project while not a requirement this helps to identify potential gaps in knowledge and further define implementation. Example list of hardware items to list include the following

  • 1 Common Test Station

Name: IO CCA JTAG Interface
Description:
The test hardware shall interface with the UUT's P1 connector, supplying power to the UUTs

The test hardware shall interface with either the 2600-0860-002 or 2600-0870-002 P2 and P3 Test and JTAG Signals connectors, respectively.

The test hardware shall interface with the 828-1A60-001 P6 and P2 connectors, provide access for Test and JTAG Signals, respectively.

 

 

CCA Signal Name Test Connector (P2) JTAG Connector (P3)
2600-0860-002 TCK Pin 4 Pin 6
TDO Pin 6 Pin 3
TDI Pin 8 Pin 2
2600-0870-002 TMS Pin 10 Pin 4
VREF (+3.3V) Pin 9 Pin 1
GND Pins 1, 3, 48, 50 Pin 5
       
  Signal Name Test Connector (P6) JTAG Connector (P2)
828-1A60-001 TCK Pin 4 Pin 6
TDO Pin 6 Pin 8
TDI Pin 8 Pin 10
TMS Pin 10 Pin 4
VREF (+3.3V) Pin 9 Pin 2
GND Pins 1, 3, 28, 48, 50 Pins 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13

*Note 2600 series does not have a ground on P2-28
